Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (herein after referred to as the Trust) is committed to meeting its responsibilities under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 (HSWA) and all associated legislation to ensure, as far as reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare of all employees and others who may be affected by its undertakings.

Falls from windows, either accidentally or intentionally, can pose a foreseeable major risk for individual accessing or supporting Trust services, on main hospital premises and/or satellite premises under the Trust's responsibility. Although instances are historically rare, the consequences of any such incident are almost always severe.
Appendix 1 gives details associated legislation and guidance that is in place which appertains to this policy.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Ensure all staff are aware of their duties laid out in this policy;

Outline the steps to be taken by the Trust to avoid falls from windows and injuries sustained from operation of windows are reduced as far as is reasonably practicable and avoid injuries sustained from impact with glazing as far as is reasonably practicable;
This policy highlights actions that need to be carried out to assist with fulfilling the duties under the legislation requirements.
This document applies to all employees of the Trust.
NHS Constitution

The Trust is committed to designing and implementing services, policies and measures that meet the diverse needs of its population and workforce, ensuring that no individual or group is disadvantaged.
This policy supports the NHS Constitution as follows:

The Trust aspires to the highest standards of excellence and professionalism in the provision of high-quality care that is safe, effective and focused on patient experience; in the planning and delivery of the clinical and other services it provides; in the people it employs and the education, training and development they receive; in the leadership and management of its organisations; and through its commitment to innovation and to the promotion and conduct of research to improve the current and future health and care of the population.
This policy supports the NHS Constitution as follows:

The Trust aspires to the highest standards of excellence and professionalism in the provision of high-quality care that is safe, effective and focused on patient experience; in the planning and delivery of the clinical and other services it provides; in the people it employs and the education, training and development they receive; in the leadership and management of its organisations; and through its commitment to innovation and to the promotion and conduct of research to improve the current and future health and care of the population.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex University Hospitals Group (MSEFT)

A fall is an event which results in the person or a body part of the person coming to rest inadvertently on the ground or other surface lower than the person, whether or not an injury is sustained. It occurs at the same level as the surface being traversed. It does not normally apply in respect of windows or balconies

Is a fall from a raised position such as from a window or a step ladder. Under the Work at Height Regulations 2005 working at “a height” is a place where the person could be injured falling from it. Slips, trips, falls (Inclusive of falls from a height) should be reported as incidents under the Trusts Adverse Incident Reporting Policy, either being recorded as a near miss or actual injury. Some of these may come under the definition of RIDDOR (see below)

RIDDOR – (Reporting of Industrial Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations). Certain incidents such as major injuries that arise out of or are in connection with work have to be reported to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). These may include falls resulting in fractures amongst other incidents. Further guidance for Managers on RIDDOR is available on the Trust Intranet.
Registered trademark of BSI (The British Standards Institution).

Healthcare Building Note (HBN 00-10 part D Windows and associated hardware is most relevant to this policy)

Approved Document K - sets standards for the design of stairways, ramps and ladders, and requirements for balustrading, windows, and vehicle barriers to prevent falling. It also includes requirements for guarding against, and warning of hazards from the use and position of doors and windows.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Trust Board and Executive Teams
Trust Board have overall responsibility for the health, safety and welfare of all staff, service users, visitors and others within all MSEFT premises.
Members of the Executive Management Team have full responsibility for the health, safety and welfare of all staff, visitors and others within the wards, offices etc. under their specific management.
All Directors have a corporate responsibility to promote a responsible approach in health and safety in the Trust.
5.1.1  Health and Safety Management Group
To receive reports from audits and inspections to gain assurance that shortfalls are being addressed.
To receive action plans from those areas where there are shortfalls.
To request follow up action if shortfalls are not addressed.
Managing Director

While ultimate responsibility is vested in the Trust Board, executive responsibility is delegated to the Managing Director for managing health and safety, including compliance with relevant legislation and Trust policies.
5.2.1 Chief Estates and Facilities Officer / EFM Directors
Have delegated responsibility for monitoring and reviewing health and safety in the Trust.
Inform Trust of health and safety matters on a regular basis and ensure adequate resources are made available to provide and maintain the necessary standards of health and safety in the Trust.
Ensures the Trust complies with this policy by meeting health and safety requirements.
Ensures adequate resources, information, consultation and training are in place and achieves compliance
5.2.2 Directors / Heads of Clinical Services

Locality Directors will bring this policy to the attention of all their staff, including new and temporary staff, and management team and ensure that it is observed at all times. They will require each team to:

Ensure risk assessments are undertaken where windows do not meet the specifications detailed in section 7 of this policy. Instrumental in developing safe systems of work is the knowledge of risks present. These risks and the control measures or safe systems of work are identified through the risk assessment process. Managers will therefore need to ensure that suitable and sufficient risk assessments have been made and that measures are identified to reduce the risk of falls from windows to the lowest level which is reasonable and practicable.
Risk assessment findings must be recorded and should be entered on the service specific risk register. Action should be taken to rectify any risks in line with good risk management process.
Ensure window restrictors and other control measures and safe systems of work as necessary are developed and implemented in accordance with this policy.
Ensure that the process is monitored and adequate support is provided for line managers to ensure that their responsibilities are met.
Ensure arrangements which implement this policy are devised and reviewed.
Play a key leadership role in developing and sustaining a pro-active culture, personal and professional responsibility for health and safety issues and work as they relate to windows safety.
5.2.3 Clinical Ward Manager, Clinical Office Managers responsibilities:
Ensure that this policy is implemented within the building area of their responsibility.
Investigate all adverse incidents and near misses and take appropriate action.
Be aware or conduct risk assessments of window safety as detailed in Section
7.2 of this policy and utilising flow chart Appendix 1 (Section 2.8 as per HBN00-
10) and forms Appendix 3 / Appendix 4 or alternatively arrange for inspection/risk assessment of window safety within area by EFM maintenance staff.

Ensure Risk assessments are reviewed annually (as part of the schedule of risk assessments) or on significant change (i.e. change of use, modification of the building or after a serious adverse incident . The significant findings of risk assessments must be communicated to staff as should the controls and recommendations given as a result of the risk assessment.

Only permit EFM maintenance staff to remove window restrictors with prior consent from the Estates or Safety department. The risks associated with any such work must be assessed by the manager prior to the work being done (seeking advice from the Estates and Health and safety departments).

Ensure that suitable and sufficient risk assessment (via the Health and Safety Team) have been made where it is contemplated that restrictors are not required or where windows do not comply with section 7.1 of this policy and that measures are identified to reduce the risk of falls from windows to the lowest level which is reasonable and practicable.

Will ensure written confirmation to the Health and Safety Team of acceptance to responsibility for ensuring behavioural (staff) controls are maintained where window restrictor removal has been agreed via risk assessment and an alternative engineered control is in place. i.e. will NOT prop open doors where a key entry pad has been fitted to an above ground level room where window restrictor removal has been agreed.

Conduct quarterly inspections of the workplace to ensure that the building remains in a safe condition. Inspections should be made with the co-operation of any accredited health and safety representatives or workplace reps and may be either part of a wider safety inspection or a dedicated inspection of window condition. In all cases written records of these inspections must be kept.

Make safe immediately (i.e. by locking it or preventing access to the room) any window that is opening beyond the safe limit or is damaged so that it is unsafe, It should also be reported for rectification to the maintenance department, via the Maintenance Provider Help Desk, as an urgent job request.

Ensure daily checks of window restrictors are undertaken in high risk buildings (those where inpatient services use rooms where windows have falls in excess of 2 metres or in wards where restrictors are fitted to prevent patients absconding). These will normally form part of daily security and environmental checks carried out by a Clinical ward team / nurse.
Take immediate action to render an area safe if for any reason the window becomes unsafe and no longer meets the specification detailed in section 7.1 of this policy.
Play a key management role in developing and sustaining a proactive culture, personal and professional responsibility for health and safety issues and work as they relate to windows safety.
5.2.4 Clinical Site Managers responsibilities:
To comply with this policy and be proactive in relation to window safety on the Trust premises.
Ensure that all instances of window safety concern are brought to the attention of the on-call estates and facilities site manager.
5.2.5 All staff:
To comply with this policy and be proactive in relation to window safety on the Trust premises.

Ensure windows that are secured (i.e. screwed or nailed shut) should not be freed and opened without also installing adequate (tamper proof) restrictors. Guidance and assessment should be sought from Estates or Safety personnel as to the type/model of restrictor that should be installed.

Ensure windows opening beyond the safe limit or are damaged and rendered unsafe should be made safe immediately (i.e. by locking it or preventing access to the room) and reporting for rectification to the relevant locality EFM helpdesk, This request should be raised as an urgent works order request, and additionally reporting the defect to a supervisor or manager.
Staff must not remove or alter or tamper with window restrictors or window unit aperture opening limiters.

Staff may only permit maintenance staff to remove window restrictors with prior consent of the EFM Directorate. The risks associated with any such work must be assessed by the manager prior to the work being completed.

Staff discovering circumstances which may threaten the health and safety of themselves or others, i.e. any defect or concern over window restrictors or a lack of window restrictors, must draw the facts to the attention of a supervisor or manager immediately.
All staff must be aware of these controls. Bank and agency staff must be informed on commencement of duties.
5.2.6 EFM (Capital Projects Team):

To ensure that the specification for windows contained within this policy is applied to the windows in the project. The Estates Department should seek additional advice as necessary from the team to occupy the building and the H&S department on specific risks to the building, i.e. specific clinical risks arising from the type of service being provided.

Ensure Design Guidance and specification guidance section of HBN 00-10 Part D are acknowledged and given due consideration when arranging new build or refurbishment projects that involve window alteration/replacement.
Ensure fire safety officer is consulted on new build and refurbishment projects to ensure fire compartmentation is appropriately maintained in line with
Trust fire safety policy
HTM 05-02 Fire code (Fire safety in the design of healthcare premises).
Fire safety: Approved document B volume 2  on rare situations where above HTM is not applicable.

To ensure when planning applications do not convey exemption that new healthcare development projects and refurbishments (where required) utilise BREEAM Healthcare (or similar assessment) to demonstrate that facilities are built with sustainability in mind. The Department of Health requires that all new builds achieve an “excellent” rating and all refurbishments achieve a “very good” rating under BREEAM Healthcare.
5.2.7 EFM Maintenance supervisors/ team leaders and operatives
To comply with this policy and be proactive in relation to window safety on the Trust premises.
Ensure all work undertaken in relation to window safety is recorded via the Trust EFM maintenance works requests system.
Ensure all work relating to window safety is undertaken within service level agreements and in accordance with this policy.
Ensure new staff are trained and informed in window safety/ restrictors / as part of local induction.
Manage the window inspection programme for windows opening onto above ground level (or leading to a level with significant injury from fall risk).
5.2.8 EFM Maintenance Manager / Responsible Persons (Including Deputies)
Ensure that this policy is implemented and embedded within maintenance operations.
Ensure that planned preventative maintenance is undertaken in accordance with this policy.
Ensure training is undertaken and recorded in line with maintenance policies.
Ensure a window asset register is fully developed, maintained and updated to reflect any changes.
5.2.9 Health and Safety Team
Ensure this policy is reviewed, and updated with any changes that may come about with changes in legislation that affects this policy.

Undertake assessment for adequacy of removal of window restrictors from ground floor level (opening onto same level) or opening onto a level that does not present a risk of level leading to a significant injury falls risk.
5.2.10 Facilities System (e.g. CAFM) Administrator - Planned Preventative Maintenance regimes
To ensure all reactive work undertaken by maintenance operatives is logged and recorded via the facilities system (e.g. CAFM).
To  ensure  all  planned  preventative  maintenance  work  orders  are issued  to maintenance operatives in accordance with the timescales referred to in this policy.
5.2.11 EFM Helpdesk
To  ensure  window  safety  work  requests  are  communicated  to  maintenance operatives in accordance with this policy to ensure safety of building occupants.
Ensure that information on all completed work orders is transferred to EFM works database system in full to enable audit trails.
Process
Assets Existing assets

For the purposes of this policy, the term Window refers to all windows within the external envelope of the Trust's premises. Internal windows in partitions and doors, in which glazing forms part, are inspected separately as part of Fire Safety Strategy and Policy.
All existing windows shall be asset marked and details of construction and condition will be recorded.
All work undertaken on windows, whether planned or otherwise, will be recorded via EFM Helpdesk and the facilities Management system for audit purposes and for informing decision making.
A full window asset survey review will be completed every 5 years by EFM Business unit or at intervals deemed appropriate by the Estates Site Manager.
Window restrictors will be inspected quarterly by EFM Maintenance or at intervals deemed appropriate by the Estates Site Manager.
Window asset registers will be updated to reflect any changes.
New assets
All new assets will meet the requirements of this Trust Specification, and comply with:
Building Regulations in force at the time of installation
Health Building Note 00-10Part D: Windows and associated hardware
Estates and Facilities Alerts
HSE guidance on window safety.
Asset registers will be updated reflect any changes.
Trust Policy

The Trust's specifications shall be applied in all cases as far as is reasonably practicable. Where for reasons of practicability a window cannot be restricted using the prescribed methods contained within this document, then a suitable and sufficient risk assessment must be undertaken. This is the operational responsibility of the senior premises manager and will be undertaken alongside the Health and Safety Team. No area will be permitted to expose any service user to a window that has the potential to cause significant injury. Various healthcare specific window safety legislation and guidance is listed within Appendix

Any derogation from Trust Specification for Window Safety will be on the advice of the Head of Health, Safety and Risk. For the purposes of this policy, derogation will only be approved where a risk assessment completed on the Trust H&S risk assessment form indicates that the window is not considered likely to create the risk of significant injury to service users and members of the public.

Where a window is not restricted and the risk assessment indicates that there is a significant risk from falls then suitable safety measures must be taken without delay and this may include cessation of clinical use for that part of the building.
All members of staff are responsible for window safety and any defects shall be reported immediately to EFM Helpdesk or Clinical and/or Estates Site Manager.
Window safety risk assessment (Refer to Appendix 1)

6.3.1 Every window shall be individually assessed or, as appropriate grouped with similar windows and covered by a risk assessment. Assessments should clearly define the areas and windows to which they apply.

6.3.2 The Stages in Assessing Windows flowchart (see Appendix 1: Section 2.8) should be used by managers to aid them in establishing the level of window safety required (if restrictors are required) for a given window and take account of the level of hazard, probability and risk that employees and others (particularly vulnerable patients) are exposed to should window restrictors not be fitted in accordance with sections  below.

6.3.3 Assessments are made to determine if a window with a fall above ground level (or opening leads to an area of significant injury from fall risk) can be exempted from having a restrictor should be approached with caution. The assessor must be sure that the mitigations in place for controlling access to a window are robust. This should not just include physical controls such as digi-locks and swipe access but also custom and practice, attitudes to security, door wedges being used and so forth. If there is doubt, given the impact of a fall, the restrictors should remain.
6.3.4 For the purposes of this policy a risk assessment shall either be:
A completed Window audit report showing that all windows comply with the standard listed in section 7.1 “Specification for window safety”.
A completed Window audit report showing that there is not a fall or leading to a fall that presents a significant risk of injury from a fall;

Or, a risk assessment risk assessment indicating that the window is not considered likely to create the risk of significant injury to service users and members of the public (for instance because it is in a location that is not a service user accessible area and is protected with appropriate access control) .

6.3.5 It should be noted that by default it is Trust policy to restrict all windows above at height that directly presents (or lead to) risk of significant injury from falling may only be exempt from this on the grounds that it is technically not reasonably practicable to restrict the window (in which case other suitable safeguards must be in place) or that the window is in a non-patient area and has adequate measures in place to prevent access. To determine if a window cannot be restricted due to technical issues the advice of the Estates and health and safety personnel is required. Where the window is not restricted and the risk assessment indicates that there is a
significant risk from falls then suitable safety measures must be taken without delay and this may include cessation of clinical use for that part of the building.

6.3.6 Windows below a height that directly presents (or lead to) risk of significant injury from falling may still be restricted but normally these are for security reasons and are not primarily for the purposes of preventing falls from a height.

6.3.7 The Trust takes the issue of health and safety with the utmost seriousness and may follow the disciplinary procedure with any individual who fails to comply with this policy or removes, damages or otherwise renders a window restrictor ineffective where a window restrictor is deemed necessary for safeguarding patients and members of the public.
Window Safety – prevention of falls
The specification that the Trust applies to windows to prevent falls is as follows:
Restrictors and fixings

7.1.1 All existing windows unless derestricted in accordance with the Trust Policy on derogation, have been restricted to a maximum of 100mm. New windows shall be restricted to an opening of a maximum 89mm utilising two independent restrictors that can only be unlocked by the use of a key or by removal of security fixings. (Note: BS EN 13126-5 recommends a maximum opening of 89 mm to prevent the passage of small children).

7.1.2 For clarity, all existing windows have had their openings restricted to prevent a 100mm sphere from passing from the interior of the building to the exterior. This applies to all windows in patient and non-patient areas across the Trust's Estate.

7.1.3 All new windows will have their openings restricted to prevent a 89mm sphere from passing from the interior of the building to the exterior. This applies to all windows in patient and non-patient areas across the Trust's Estate.
7.1.4 The Trust standard for window restrictors is as follows:
a) Jackloc- wire type, key lockable restrictors, used with security fixings.
b) Fixed or key operated integral restrictors with security screws
All restrictors must be of robust construction, capable of withstanding a high degree of
abuse.
c) Screw fixings for restrictors of any kind
must be tamper proof type with 6 lobe pin heads  or similar approved.
Standard flat head and cross head
screws are not permitted.
Restrictors must not be defeatable, without the need for a specialist tool or key.

All windows will have a minimum of two independent key or tool lockable restrictors as standard. This is to address the potential risks identified in Estates and Facilities Alert Ref: EFA/2012/001, issued  January 2012.
All proprietary restrictors must have published load test results, details of which are to be held within the EFM asset logging system.

It is Trust Policy that the only acceptable method of securing window restrictors is by use of security screws and bolts in all cases, unless agreed by Estates Site Manager, Head of Maintenance in collaboration with the Health and safety Team.
Keys for the removal and / or unlocking of restrictors are for maintenance or security purposes only and all existing keys held by other staff must be handed over to EFM Maintenance.
All keys for such purposes are restricted and EFM operates a strict and secure procedure for signing out keys for maintenance and security purposes.
All maintenance and security officers shall formally sign out keys held for unlocking restrictors. Security will only use such keys for emergencies and to lock/ unlock windows for security purposes.
Maintenance staff will only use such keys for emergencies and for maintenance purposes.
External  contractors  who  need  to  unlock  windows  for  access  or  maintenance purposes are required to abide by the Trusts Permit to Work system and key logging procedures and ensure.
Window safety – prevention of injury due to impact. the
specification that the Trust applies to windows to reduce the risk of injury arising from impact is as follows:
Glazing

All window glazing within external and internal walls (including vision panels in doors) shall comply with the Management of Health & Safety (Workplace) Regulations 1992 in that all glazing in exposed areas shall be constructed to meet the following Building Regulations and British Standards as a minimum:
Part K of Schedule 1 to the Building regulations 2010.
BS  This policy covers all external glazing within the Trust building envelope. Internal glazing forms part of the Trust's Fire Safety Policy and Strategy.
BS 6206:  ‘Specification for Impact Performance Requirements for Flat Safety Glass and Safety Plastics for use in Buildings'.
BS 6262: ‘Code of practice for glazing for buildings' Part 4: 1994 ‘Safety related to human impact'

Retrospectively this has been achieved either by filming the glass or replacement with appropriate safety glass in all “Critical Locations” as defined by Building Regulations 2010 Approved Document K. It should be noted that this is a minimum standard and that some units may have higher specification glazing which has been arrived at by risk assessment. E.g. Fire rated.

All new windows will comprise insulating glass units to BS EN 1279 and be Kite mark  certified  or  otherwise labelled  appropriately  to  designate  compliance  with British standards for Safety Glazing.
New Glazing

All new glazing installations will comprise laminated or toughened glass components to comply with BS EN 12600: Glass in building – Pendulum test – Impact test method and classification for flat glass and shall carry a kite mark with clear labelling depicting the relevant category under which the installation complies. All installations are to comply with current Building Regulations and Health Building Note 00-10Part D: Windows and associated hardware.
Replacement glazing

Any replacement glazing will comprise minimum toughened or laminated safety glass units as standard to comply with BS EN 12600: 2002 and shall carry a kite mark with clear labelling depicting the relevant category under which the installation complies. All installations are to comply with current Building Regulations and Health Building Note 00-10 Part D: Windows and associated hardware.
Existing glazing

Existing glazing within “Critical Locations” has received safety film and been labelled to indicate compliance with BSEN 12600: 2002 or BS6206 and relevant Sub Category/ Class of compliance. Where filming has not been feasible, glazing has been replaced (see Replacement glazing section 7.4.1). All installations are to comply with current Building Regulations and Health Building Note 00-10 Part D: Windows and associated hardware.

Existing glazing within enhanced supervision rooms throughout the Trust has safety film applied to all glazing as standard regardless of the presence of “critical locations”. It is the clinical leads' responsibility to inform Estates of any proposals relating to room use changes so that window safety issues can be addressed.
Cleaning and maintenance
Cleaning

All new installations will allow for cleaning of internal and external surfaces without use of ladders wherever possible. A copy of this policy will be issued to Estates and maintenance staff and as appropriate to technical advisors, referred to within Designers' Risk Assessments for the Purposes of fulfilling Construction Design Management Regulations 2015.
Maintenance Works, Inspections, Records and Auditing

9.2.1 All windows and window restrictors will be subject to routine inspection by the EFM Directorate. The Window restrictor inspection procedure in Appendix 2 must be followed, by trained personnel. Any window found to be in a poor condition will be subject to repair or replacement as appropriate and within a timescale appropriate to the level of defect. Where window safety fails to meet the standard of this policy and is deemed unsafe following risk assessment by a Competent Person, the area may be taken out of use until repairs are completed.
9.2.2 Records of window restrictor inspections for large numbers of windows and window safety inspections will utilise the same Standard Form (Appendix 4). The criteria will include:
If the window is fitted with restrictors.
The size of the window gap in its opened but restricted state, (100mm / 89mm - (BS EN 13126-5 recommends new window 89mm aperture opening restriction to prevent passage of small children).
Whether the restrictor is of robust construction (i.e. showing signs of weakness, working loose, missing or loose screws etc.)
Whether the fixings used to secure the restrictor to the window require specialist tools or not,
Whether the restrictor can be removed without the need for a specialist tool
9.2.3 Records of reactive window restrictor inspections for singular windows will utilise the Standard Form shown in Appendix
9.2.4 Records for each window must be traceable over the period of inspection.
9.2.5 Results of inspections will be reviewed and used to modify the inspection period as necessary and in line with recommendations of the review.

N.B. Where window restrictors are fitted, they are included on EFM planned preventative maintenance and monitoring schedules. The frequency of inspection will follow the manufacturer's advice and will depend partly on experience gained from the inspection. For example, when new restrictors are fitted, inspection should be frequent and should look for evidence of damage and wear or of devices being defeated/ defective. Future frequency of inspections can then be determined by risk assessment.

9.2.6 The EFM inspection will ensure that devices fitted are designed to resist reasonable forces being applied by adults (for example, where determined adults may use impact forces to open the window beyond its 89mm / 100mm restriction (BS EN 13126-5 recommends new window 89mm aperture opening restriction to prevent passage of small children).

9.2.7 Some integral restrictors may not be sufficiently robust. Attention should also be given to the method of fixing to the window frame as different materials may give different performance results. The forms within Appendix 3&4 are utilised for EFM maintenance operatives log inspections.
9.2.8 Frequency of inspection may be decreased if damage or failure is never encountered – but it will always be required and will also need to be documented as part of the risk assessment process.

9.2.9 Depending on the style and size, even with restrictors fitted, certain windows can flex beyond the designated 89mm/ 100mm maximum opening when forces are applied by determined adults. Friction stays, when worn, further add to the ability of the window to flex and can allow the opening to widen under pressure. To provide reassurance that the restrictor will limit the initial opening to a maximum of 89mm / 100mm under foreseeable force, professional advice will be sought with regard to site-specific testing methods.
Training requirements
Awareness in window safety and falls from a height are generated by a number of processes within the Trust, and include:
Publication of this policy on Trust Intranet
Communications bulletins including Friday Round up
EFM Intranet pages
Health and Safety and PLACE meetings.
Workplace inspections
Toolbox talks to maintenance and security operatives
On-going regular internal PLACE inspections
Retention, disposal and archiving
Promulgated  procedural  documents  are  formal  corporate  records  and  shall  be managed in accordance with the Trust's Records Management Policy.
An audit trail of all previous versions of documents is required for auditing purposes and shall be stored by EFM Directorate.
Master copies of documents will be archived. A register of archived documents will be retained by EFM Directorate. Copies of archived documents shall be available on request.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Management Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and procedures. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and Safety Management Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
All Heads of Department / Managers / Site Leads will be responsible for issuing copies to senior operational managers for them to disseminate within their wards and departments.
The Head of Maintenance for each site will be responsible for ensuring all Estates staff read and fully understand the policy and is read in conjunction with the Control of Contractors Policy.

The Broomfield / Braintree Community Hospital PFI Estate Manager will be responsible for ensuring all PFI Estate staff read and fully understand the policy and is read in conjunction with the Control of Contractors Policy.

All MSE Satellite site premises Estate Manager will be responsible for ensuring all Estate staff (PFI and NHS Employees) read and fully understand the policy and is read in conjunction with the Control of Contractors Policy.

Appendix 1: Window safety associated legislation, assessment and audit criteria
The following legislation applies to Employers' duties to service users: Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974, Section 3

HSWA section 3 places general duties on the Trust as employers to conduct their undertakings in such a way as to ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that persons other than themselves or their employees are not exposed to risks to their health or safety.
Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999, Regulation 3

This regulation requires all the Trust as employers to assess the risks to workers and any others who may be affected by their work or business. This will enable them to identify the measures they need to take to comply with health and safety law. The Trust should carry out a systematic general examination of the effect of their undertaking, their work activities and the condition of the premises and record the significant findings of that risk assessment.
Complying with the following legislation, dealing with employers' duties to employees, will also help reduce the risk to service users:
Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations

Regulation 14 applies to glazing material and where necessary requires windows to be constructed of safety material (e.g. safety glass) or otherwise protected against breakage (e.g. by means of a screen or barrier). The Approved Code of Practice (ACOP) states that if a person going through the glass would fall from a height, and a screen / barrier is used, then it should be designed to be difficult to climb.

Regulation 15 applies to risks associated with windows, skylights and ventilators. Where there is a risk of falling from height, the ACOP requires provision of devices that prevent the window opening too far (e.g. window restrictors). The bottom edge of openable windows should be at least 800 mm above floor level, unless there is a barrier to prevent falls.
Approved Document K 2013 to the Building Regulations 2010. Main points
Protection against impact with glazing.
K4 Glazing, with which people are likely to come into contact whilst moving in or about the building
shall:
a) If broken on impact, break in a way which is unlikely to cause injury; or
b) Resist impact without breaking; or
c) Be shielded or protected from impact
These areas are defined under Building Regulations as “Critical Locations”

Protection from collision with open window etc
K5.1 provision shall be made to prevent people moving in or about the building from colliding with open windows, skylights or ventilators. See section K5.1 section  for suggested protective measures.
Manfestation of Glazing
K5.2 transparent galzing, with which people are likely to come into contact while moving in or about the building, shall incorporate features which make it apparent.
Other Guidance and Approved Code of Practice
Health Building Note 00-10 Part D: Windows and associated hardware

This guidance recognises that window restrictors tested to current British Standards may be inadequate in preventing a determined effort to force a window open beyond the 100mm restriction. The relevant tests for restrictors cited in BS EN 14351-1 and BS EN 13126-5 have been developed to prevent accidental falling from windows.
BS EN 14351-1 recommends that restrictors must be able to hold a window in place for 60 seconds when a static load of 350Newtons is applied to that window.

However, these static loads may not be sufficient to prevent determined patients who want to force the window beyond its 100 mm restriction. None of the British and European Standards deal with deliberate attempts to defeat the restrictor using impact forces, which may be the situation encountered in hospitals and care homes.

In the absence of an established performance standard, this HBN recommends that loads on window restrictors used in healthcare are tested using forces in excess of those quoted in BS EN 14351 and BS EN 13126-5. (Note also that BS EN 13126-5 recommends a maximum opening of  mm to prevent the passage of small children.)
Window safety assessment and restrictor selection (Extracted from HBN 00-10 Part D Appendix 2 published 2013)
To prevent falls from windows, it is important to assess all windows to which patients have access.
There is a need to assess the suitability and functionality (fitness for purpose) of those windows that are already fitted with restrictors to determine whether:
a suitably acceptable restrictor is already in place: the restrictor should be of the appropriate design and type to match the window style and construction materials;
the restrictor is fit for purpose;
a replacement or additional restrictor is needed;
the window is functional and safe for use.
For mental health facilities, risk assessment should be undertaken to determine the most appropriate windows, fittings and devices.
Preparation: documenting the assessment for reference

Ensure  suitably  experienced/trained  staff  are  conducting  the  assessment.  Only competent staff with the necessary skills and experience in the following disciplines should be involved in any window safety self-assessment:
Window safety assessment and restrictor selection Assessment methodology and key points
Operate the window to assess the following:
Does the restrictor meet the minimum requirements for restrictors defined in paragraph 3.27
Do the window and restrictor (if fitted) operate/function correctly?
Are existing restrictors fit for purpose (for example, is the restrictor/frame arrangement sufficiently robust to withstand determined efforts by patients to open it further)?
Do restrictors (and/or other hardware) need replacing/installing due to wear and tear or corrosion?
Note
Cable restrictors are not suitable for mental health units and where anti-ligature regulations need to be complied with.

Alternative options
Choose an experienced external assessor. Archiving of documented assessment results

Frequency of assessments and maintenance recommendations
The frequency of assessments and maintenance will be influenced by information supplied by manufacturers, initial inspections, on-going monitoring, and local reporting of defects and failures
Other guidance
HSE Information Sheet No 5: Falls from Windows or balconies in health and social care August 2012
Risk assessment

To adequately manage the risk of falls from windows or balconies, the Trust needs to assess the premises and service users. Where assessment identifies that individuals are at risk from falls then adequate arrangements should be in place.
This should include assessing the risk that furniture, or other items, may enable them to climb over barriers, or access windows which might otherwise be inaccessible.
Control measures
Suitable controls may include:
Fitting adequate window restrictors;
Ensuring balconies have edge protection that is sufficiently robust, and of suitable design (including height, and the size of any openings in it), to prevent accidental falls;
Fitting an adequate screen or barrier to prevent service user access to a window or balcony edge;
Restricting access to upper floors.
Window restrictors
Where vulnerable people have access to windows large enough to allow them to fall out and be harmed, those windows should be restrained sufficiently to prevent such falls. Window restrictors should:
Restrict the window opening to 100 mm or less; (BS EN 13126-5 recommends new window 89mm aperture opening restriction to prevent passage of small children).
Be suitably robust to withstand foreseeable forces applied by an individual determined to open the window further;
Be sufficiently robust to withstand damage (either deliberate or from general wear);

Be robustly secured using tamper-proof fittings so they cannot be removed or disengaged using readily accessible implements (such as cutlery) and require a special tool or key. Please note that ‘safety restricted hinges' that limit the initial opening of a window can be overridden without the use of any tools and are not suitable in health and social care premises where individuals are identified as being vulnerable to the risk of falls from windows.
The Trust should also:
Ensure the window frames to which restrictors are fitted are sufficiently robust;

Consider any impact on the comfort of service users from reduced natural ventilation and provide adequate cooling where necessary (e.g. high-level and/or restricted aperture ventilation, fans or air conditioning). The NHS has produced separate guidance on dealing with extreme heat and heat waves.
Balconies

Where assessment identifies that service users are at risk of falling, then sufficient protection should be provided to prevent them from accessing balconies or climbing over the balcony edge protection. This should take into account furniture or features with footholds which may allow access over the barrier (e.g. chairs, tables, plant pots, walls etc.).
Restricting access to upper floors

Where service users are at risk of falling, the care provider must decide whether to apply protective measures throughout the premises, or to ensure that they only have access to safe areas, for example the ground floor.
Maintenance
Maintenance must ensure that all safety fixtures and fittings are functioning effectively and their performance has not deteriorated as a result of use, wear or tampering.
Training

Adequate training and supervision should be provided to ensure that members of staff understand the risks, the precautions required, and the need to report any defects or concerns to a responsible person.
Extracted from HBN 00-10 Part D Windows and Associated hardware (published 2013) Safety: Falls from windows
There is a need to assess the risks of patients falling from windows. This risk assessment should take account of patient category and physical capability.
Note:
This risk assessment applies not only to new builds or refurbishments – but also to all existing stock. If the type of occupancy significantly changes, the risks should be reassessed.
If risks from falling are identified, then control measures should be put in place. This usually involves the use of windows with restrictors and, where risk assessment dictates, safety glazing.

For the purposes of this document, the term “restrictor” is used to define any mechanical device that limits the movement of an opening light so that an opening of not more than 100 mm is achieved at any point even with the application of a significant additional opening force. It can either be fixed (that is, cannot be overridden) or can only be overridden by means of a removable key or other device. They should only be fitted using tamper-proof fixings. The size of the opening can be validated using a 100 mm sphere or other such measuring device.
Note:

Other design options are also available. For example, windows are available that incorporate a discreet tamper-proof safety screen. These have the added benefit of allowing better natural ventilation as the window need not be restricted to a 100 mm opening.
Safety glazing

Regulation  of the Workplace (Health Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 imposes on those responsible, a duty to undertake a risk assessment of their glazing in critical locations to identify any glass that could create a risk of injury to the building's users or visitors. Critical glazing locations are given in Approved Document K of the Building Regulations.
Any requirements for the use of safety glazing should comply with BS 6262-4.

Any fixed glazing less than 800 mm above floor level which acts as a barrier to prevent people falling out should be replaced with glazing which meets the impact resistance requirements of BS 6262-4 taking into account Approved Document K for containment.
The use of safety glazing should also be considered in spaces that are accessible to children or vulnerable patients.
Window safety assessment and restrictor selection
4.30 As a minimum, restrictors should conform to BS EN 14351-1 + A1 and BS EN 13126-5 (see also BS 8213-1)

Note: This guidance recognises that window restrictors tested to current British Standards may be inadequate in preventing a determined effort to force a window open beyond the 100 mm restriction. The relevant tests for restrictors cited in BS EN 14351-1 and BS EN 13126-5 have been developed to prevent accidental falling from windows. BS EN 14351-1 recommends that restrictors must be able to hold a window in place for  seconds when a static load of  newtons is applied to that window. However, these static loads may not be sufficient to prevent determined patients who want to force the window beyond its 100 mm restriction. None of the British and European Standards deal with deliberate attempts to defeat the restrictor using impact forces, which may be the situation encountered in hospitals and care homes. In the absence of an established performance standard, it is recommended that loads on window restrictors used in healthcare are tested using forces in excess of those quoted in BS EN 14351 and BS EN 13126-5. (Note also that BS EN 13126-5 recommends a maximum opening of 89 mm to prevent the passage of small children.) Two publications (see below) contain the most up-to-date ergonomic data on adult push forces from a standing position. The data in these documents can be used as a guide to the amount of force to be exerted when testing the restrictor.
Maintenance of restrictors

Where window restrictors are fitted, they should be included on planned preventative maintenance and monitoring schedules. The frequency of inspection should follow the manufacturer's advice and will depend partly on experience gained from the inspection. For example, when new restrictors are fitted, inspection should be frequent and should look for evidence of damage and wear or of devices being defeated/defective. Future frequency of inspections can then be determined by risk assessment.

Inspection should ensure that devices fitted are designed to resist reasonable forces being applied by adults (for example, where determined adults may use impact forces to open the window beyond its  mm restriction). Some integral restrictors may not be sufficiently robust. Attention should also be given to the method of fixing to the window frame as different materials may give different performance results.

Where a damaged, defeated or defective restrictor is found, questions should always be asked about the significance of the finding and any wider implications, and a programme to repair or replace the restrictor put in place. The risk assessment should also be reviewed.

Frequency of inspection may be decreased if damage or failure is never encountered – but   Maintenance and replacement it will always be required and will also need to be documented as part of the risk assessment process.

Depending on the style and size, even with restrictors fitted, certain windows can flex beyond the designated 100 mm maximum opening when forces are applied by determined adults. Friction stays, when worn, further add to the ability of the window to flex and can allow the opening to widen under pressure. To provide reassurance that the restrictor will limit the initial opening to a maximum of 100 mm under foreseeable force, it is recommended that professional advice is sought with regard to site-specific testing methods. For further guidance, see Estates and Facilities Alert Notice 2013/002 – ‘Window restrictors'.
